article.Heading: GST narrows the gap between iPhone's offline and online prices
article.Summary: Earlier, online retailers used to supply the phones from states where Value Added Tax was lower, said a report by The Economic Times. However, with GST, there is a uniform tax rate across India.
article.Body:
Moneycontrol News

The introduction of the Goods and Services Tax (GST) on July 1 has narrowed the difference between online and offline prices of iPhone to Rs 1,500-Rs 2,000 from Rs 5,000-Rs 8,000 earlier.

Earlier, online retailers used to supply the phones from states where Value Added Tax was lower, said a report by The Economic Times. However, with GST, there is a uniform tax rate across India.

Retailers now can pass on only the savings in distribution and storage cost to the customers. Quoting executives, the report said that the distributors were resorting to a uniform margin across sales channels.

The same practice was employed by other e-retailers, especially, online-exclusive brands. Now, since the uniform tax regime is in force, prices of such commodities may go up.

Another Tryst With Destiny! How GST Will Change Your Life After July 1

Around half of the Apple phones sold in India are through e-commerce sites.

The offline business of iPhone is expected to grow faster now, according to retail chain Hotspot’s executive director Subhasish Mohanty, who was quoted in the report. Earlier, there was a drop of 35 percent in offline business for iPhone due to discounts in the online sphere.

Apple India overtook Micromax, with a 54 percent increase in turnover, to become the second largest smartphone company in the country in terms of revenue in 2015-16.
